member.name: T:Infrastructure.Seedwork.ActionExecutionContext
member.summary: Holds data tracked by policies during an action run.

remarks.p: There are two kinds of data tracked by policies during an action run: 1. Data for a single execution of the action. This data is reset if the action fails and is retried. This data is called RunData. 2. Data across multiple executions of the action (which happens if the action fails and is retried). This data is called SharedData.

member.author: Vamsee M Kamabathula

member.name: M:Infrastructure.Seedwork.Configuration.TypeExtensions.IsInNamespace(System.Type,System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if has a namespace and it starts with .

remarks.p:
Consider a Customer class in namespace Demo.Objects (i.e., Demo.Objects.Customer is the namespace qualified class name). This method returns true in the following scenarios:
1. TypeExtensions.IsInNamespace(typeof(Customer), "Demo")
2. TypeExtensions.IsInNamespace(typeof(Customer), "Demo.Objects")
Note: The namespace is case sensitive, so "Demo" is different from "demo".

member.param: Type to be tested.
Namespace to be tested.
member.returns: true if the is part of the specified .

member.summary: Extension methods on used by the .

member.name: M:Infrastructure.Seedwork.Configuration.TypeScannerExtentions.GetPredicate(Infrastructure.Seedwork.Configuration.ITypeScanner)
member.summary: Creates a predicate that filters types based on the types the scanner is interested in.
member.remarks:
A type scanner can specify types of interest in the following ways:
Classes that are part of the namespace property should be passed to the method. To determine whether a type is part of a namespace, is called.
A type scanner can implement to specify the specific type (and all its sub types) it is interested in.
If more than one criteria (namespace, assembly and type) is specified by a type scanner, then the predicate returns true only if the type matches each specified criteria.
If a criteria is not specified (for e.g., namespace is null), then that criteria is ignored.
member.returns: A predicate that filters types based on the types the is interested in.

member.name: M:Infrastructure.Seedwork.Configuration.TypeScannerExtentions.GetTypeOfInterest(Infrastructure.Seedwork.Configuration.ITypeScanner)
member.summary: Returns the type of interest to the .

remarks.p: To determine the type of interest, we check if the implements and return the generic type argument. If the scanner does not implement , this method returns null.

member.returns: The type of interest to the or null if the scanner does not implement .

member.name: T:Infrastructure.Seedwork.DeterministicGuidGenerator
member.summary: Utility class for converting a string value to a guid.

remarks.p: We are evaluating if we can use NEventStore (http://neventstore.org/) for implementing EventSourcing in our products. However, current implementation of NEventStore uses Guid values for stream identity. The method generates the same Guid value for the a given string (case sensitive). And it is rare for two strings to result in the same Guid value.
This implementation is based on the blog post (http://geekswithblogs.net/EltonStoneman/archive/2008/06/26/generating-deterministic-guids.aspx) by Elton Stoneman.

member.name: T:Infrastructure.Seedwork.DI.IObjectPool`1
member.summary: Represents a pool of objects.

remarks.p: In order to speed up processing of requests that require objects that are expensive to create, we use an object pool that contains a set of pre created objects. When a request comes in, an object is retrieved from the pool by calling method. method is used to populate the pool with new objects. As objects are returned by the pool, it raises the event that can be used to populate the pool with new objects. The pool itself does not care about the population strategy, it just holds a pool of objects and returns them in a thread safe manner.

member.typeparam: The type of objects returned by the pool.

member.name: M:Infrastructure.Seedwork.DI.IObjectPool`1.GetObject
member.summary: Get an object from the pool.
member.remarks: If the pool is empty when this method is invoked, the pool will use a factory method to create a new instance of .
member.exception: If a factory method is not set.
member.returns: An instance of .

member.name: M:Infrastructure.Seedwork.Domain.IAggregateRoot`3.Execute(`2)
member.summary: Executes the specified command on the aggregate.

remarks.p: An aggregate state can be changed by executing commands on it. Commands are validated before the aggregate can be modified. If a command is invalid, the method should throw an exception. If the command is valid, it is translated into one or more events which are then passed to the method to change the state of the aggregate.

Each event generated by the command will result in the version number of the aggregate increasing by one. So if the current version of an aggregate is 5, and a command is executed on it resulting in two events, then the new version of the aggregate is 7.

member.name: T:Infrastructure.Seedwork.Data.UnitOfWorkScope
member.summary: Instances of this class manage the scope for executing a unit of work.

remarks.p:
Executing a unit of work typically involve the following actions:
Manage an IContainer
To execute code in a unit of work, we need to create a child container that creates objects required for executing the work.
Manage a TransactionScope
The unit of work must execute in a transaction scope so that if an error occurs, the incomplete work is rolled back.
Persist changes
The new generation ORM (object relational mapping) tools like NHibernate, Entity Framework, etc track object changes in memory. So before a transaction scope can be completed, the in memory changes must be flushed to disk. This is the responsibility of instances. At the begining of some work, we must create instances of registered in the child and call . At the end of the work, before calling , we must call so that the in memory changes are flushed to disk.
Repeating the above steps every time we need to do a unit of work (which is like all the time in a business application as everything is a unit of work) is very cumbersome and breaks DRY (don't repeat yourself) principle.
UnitOfWorkScope tries to solve this problem by managing the above three aspects of executing code in a unit of work.

member.author: Vamsee M Kamabathula

member.name: F:Infrastructure.Seedwork.Data.UnitOfWorkScope._isCompleted
member.summary: Set to true when is called on this instance.
member.remarks: If this is false, then the transaction scope of this instance is rolled back.

member.name: M:Infrastructure.Seedwork.Data.UnitOfWorkScope.Complete
member.summary: Marks the unit of work as complete.

remarks.p: If a unit of work scope is marked as complete, the transaction in which the work is executed will be marked as complete. Conversely, if a unit of work scope is disposed without calling complete, then the transaction is rolled back.
Disposing a scope without calling Complete will result in the transaction being rolled back.

member.name: M:Infrastructure.Seedwork.Data.UnitOfWorkScope.SetError(System.Exception)
member.summary: If an unhandled exception is thrown during processing of a unit of work, it can be set on the unit of work scope to indicate that the unit of work should be rolled back.

remarks.p: Once an error is set on an instance, it cannot be marked as . Conversely, once an instance is marked as , error cannot be set.

Even if an error is not set on an instance, the transaction will still be rolledback at the time of disposal if was not called. Setting the error just helps in debugging and is not a mandatory requirement.

member.param: The error to be set.
member.exception: If is null.
If was already called on this instance.

member.name: T:Infrastructure.Seedwork.DI.IConfigurableContainer
member.summary: Interface to be exposed by containers that can be configured programatically.

remarks.p: IoC containers like Spring.NET support configuration through XML files. However, doing the complete configuration by XML files would be very difficult to manage as it would be too verbose and the XML files would have to be copied to different application modules or components (like reporting, web app, tools, integrator, etc).

In addition, there is really no value add to having the XML file files if we are not passing in any application settings through the configuration. Take the classic example of unit of work and repository patterns. A repository needs a unit of work object and unit of work object is some pre defined class defined in the infrastructure implementation. There is no point in wiring these types using XML. In such scenarios, we are better off configuring the objects using code instead of XML files.
IConfigurableContainer implementations allow us to configure a container from code, thus reducing duplicated configuration across application modules / components.

A container is configurable only if it hasn't been used to build objects. If either of the build methods (Build, BuildAll and BuildChildContainer) is called on a container, it is initialized. After the initialization is done, calling any methods defined by this interface should result in System.InvalidOperationException being thrown.

member.author: Vamsee M Kamabathula

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.CanBeNullAttribute

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.ContractAnnotationAttribute
member.summary: Describes dependency between method input and output.
member.syntax:
Function Definition Table syntax:
FDT ::= FDTRow [;FDTRow]*
FDTRow ::= Input => Output | Output <= Input
Input ::= ParameterName: Value [, Input]*
Output ::= [ParameterName: Value]* {halt|stop|void|nothing|Value}
Value ::= true | false | null | notnull | canbenull
If method has single input parameter, it's name could be omitted.
Using halt (or void/nothing, which is the same) for method output means that the methos doesn't return normally.
canbenull annotation is only applicable for output parameters.
You can use multiple [ContractAnnotation] for each FDT row, or use single attribute with rows separated by semicolon.

item.code: [ContractAnnotation("halt <= condition: false")] public void Assert(bool condition, string text) // Regular Assertion method
[ContractAnnotation("s:null => true")] public bool IsNullOrEmpty(string s) // String.IsNullOrEmpty
[ContractAnnotation("s:null=>false; =>true,result:notnull; =>false, result:null")] public bool TryParse(string s, out Person result)

member.name: T:Infrastructure.Seedwork.Messaging.ICommandBus
member.summary: A bus that sends commands to respective command handlers.

remarks.p: The commands sent on the bus could be executed in the same app domain, a different app domain in the same process or a different process on the same machine or a different process on another machine.
There is no guarantee that all the commands will execute in the same process. Commands may be routed to different machines based on the bus configuration.
The commands are usually executed asynchronously.

member.author: Vamsee M Kamabathula

member.name: M:Infrastructure.Seedwork.Messaging.ICommandBus.Send(Infrastructure.Seedwork.Messaging.ICommand)
member.summary: Sends the specified command to the command handlers.
member.remarks: The command is sent to the handler aynchronously. So this method may return before the command is executed.
member.param: The command to be sent. This must not be null.

member.name: M:Infrastructure.Seedwork.Messaging.ICommandBus.Send(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Infrastructure.Seedwork.Messaging.ICommand})
member.summary: Sends the specified commands to the respective command handlers.

remarks.p: The bus implementation may choose to execute all the commands in the same unit of work. While this is not guaranteed, it will be honoured most of the times (unless the commands get routed to different machines/processes).
So clients that want a batch of commands to be executed in a unit of work must use this method instead of calling Send(ICommand) in a loop.

member.param: The command to be sent. This must not be null.

Represent an Expression Specification
Specification overload operators for create AND, OR or NOT specifications. Additionally overload AND and OR operators with the same sense of ( binary And and binary Or ). C# couldnt overload the AND and OR operators directly since the framework doesnt allow such craziness. But with overloading false and true operators this is posible. summary.syntax: Case [Expression/Operand] When [condition/operand] Then [Result] Else Result End
summary.example: 1. Case When x > y Then z Else NULL End 2. Case x When y Then z Else NULL End

member.name: P:Infrastructure.Seedwork.Sql.CaseExpression.Operand
member.summary: Operand is optional.it is the value that we are comparing to the list of conditions. /// 1. Case When x > y Then z Else NULL End ** In this example we are omitting the Operand. 2. Case x When y Then z Else NULL End ** In this example "x" is Operand. Condition would be "x = y".

member.name: P:Infrastructure.Seedwork.Sql.CaseExpression.DefaultResult
member.summary:
DefaultResult is the value if no condition is found to be true, then the case statement will return this.
1. Case When x > y Then z Else Result End 2. Case x When y Then z Else Result End ** In above two example "Result" is the default result.
If the else clause is omitted and no condition is found to be true, then the Case statement will return Null.

member.name: T:Infrastructure.Seedwork.Sql.WhenClause
member.summary: When clause is part of Case expression. When [condition/operand] Then [Result]
member.example: 1. Case When x > y Then z Else NULL End 2. Case x When y Then z Else NULL End
member.author: Vamsee M Kamabathula

member.name: P:Infrastructure.Seedwork.Sql.WhenClause.Operand
member.summary:
Operand can be condition or a value that is equated with case operand.
1. Case When x > y Then z Else NULL End ** In this example "x > y" is Operand. 2. Case x When y Then z Else NULL End ** In this example "y" is Operand. Condition would be "x = y".

member.name: P:Infrastructure.Seedwork.Sql.WhenClause.Result
member.summary:
Result is the value returned once the conition is true.
1. Case When x > y Then z Else NULL End 2. Case x When y Then z Else NULL End ** In above two example "z" is result if when condition is satisfied else "NULL".
